Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my girlfriend’s last message still glowing on the screen: “We need to talk. I can’t keep doing this if we don’t figure things out.” My heart pounded, knowing our argument had spiraled out of control. She expected me to step up, to resolve this, to show her that I cared enough to fight for us. I wanted to call her, to say the right words, to fix what was breaking between us.

But just as I reached for the phone, it buzzed again—this time, my work line. A new client, cheerful but clueless, wanted to know how to safely start up the machine I’d just serviced. “Could you walk me through the basics?” he asked, his tone light, but I knew he was counting on me to be patient and clear, to guide him so he wouldn’t make a costly mistake.

I felt pulled in two directions, my mind racing. My girlfriend needed me now, but so did my client. Both expected me to be present, to solve their problems, to be the person they could rely on. My hands shook as I hovered between calls, torn by the weight of what each role demanded from me.
